data.title: I flew on a tiny plane to Barra, a Scottish island with the only airport in the world where commercial flights land directly on the beach
data.meta_description: Insider's author flew to Barra, a Scottish island that some compare to the Caribbean for its white sandy beaches. The flight there was memorable.
data.text:

My partner and I spent an unforgettable weekend on Barra, a beautiful island in Scotland.

Barra is a western island in Scotland's Outer Hebrides which is known for its natural beauty.

I was intrigued to visit this past weekend after reading that Barra's white sandy beaches have been compared to the Caribbean. The island has been nicknamed "Barrabados" and "Barradise" by locals, according to the Daily Mail.

After spending two days on the island, I concur that its beaches are gorgeous and unlike anything I'd ever seen in Scotland. I also overheard fellow tourists referring to the island as "Barrabados," which gave me a chuckle.

Advertisement

One of the most fascinating things about the island is its airport.

From our home in Glasgow, Barra is accessible via ferry from Oban, which takes just under five hours, or by plane which takes just over one hour from Glasgow Airport.

We initially planned to take the ferry, but a couple of days before our visit we noticed there had been some last-minute cancellations due to poor weather conditions. We swiftly changed our plans and purchased a round-trip flight with the Scottish airline Loganair.

I was excited because of what I'd read about Barra Airport: It's the only airport in the world where scheduled commercial flights use a tidal beach as the runway, according to the Highlands and Islands Airport.

The airport is a tourist attraction and the beach is accessible to the public when flights aren't operating.

The round-trip cost £164, or around $199, per person.

Advertisement

We began our journey at Glasgow Airport.

Our flight departed from Glasgow Airport, where I have journeyed many times over the years. However, this adventure was different from the outset.

When booking our tickets a couple of days in advance, I was shown an online seating chart which revealed that the plane we were due to board had only 19 seats.

When our gate was called, my partner and I made our way to a small waiting area. There were a total of 13 passengers waiting to board the plane, including us.

Advertisement

Boarding the plane was a smooth and easy process.

The flight was delayed by around 40 minutes, but we didn't mind the wait. Unlike what I usually experience, there was a lack of noise and commotion at our gate, which made the waiting peaceful and stress-free.

When it was time to board, we formed a small line and made it onto the plane in a matter of minutes.

Advertisement

There were 13 passengers and no flight attendants on board.

A man who I initially thought was a flight attendant stood outside the plane and welcomed every passenger on board. It wasn't until we took our seats that the man introduced himself as the pilot.

There were no flight attendants on board — only the pilot and the captain — and the pilot was the one to go through the flight safety instructions before taking off.

He asked that we keep our seat belts on for the entire duration of the journey and that all electronic devices be switched off or on airplane mode.

Advertisement

We were seated near the front of the aircraft.

My partner had a window seat and I had an aisle seat; we were just a couple of rows from the cockpit at the front of the plane.

One thing I immediately noticed was the lack of amenities that you would find on most planes. For example, there was no toilet on the plane, no overhead lockers to store our belongings, and no tray tables.

Advertisement

I was thankful that the seat across the aisle was empty — I used it to store my belongings.

My partner had a small suitcase that was put in the hold before we boarded the plane. However, because I only had a backpack, I decided to take it on board with me, assuming that I would be able to place it in an overhead compartment — but there were none.

Most people on board placed belongings at their feet. But luckily for me, the seat across the aisle was vacant, so I ended up using it as storage space for my bag and jacket.

Advertisement

There wasn't a lot of leg room.

There wasn't a lot of legroom, so I was thankful that I was able to use the seat across from me to store my luggage.

The lack of a tray table was also difficult to get used to, especially as I had brought a hot chocolate that I had purchased from the airport onto the plane. Thankfully, there were pockets on the seats in front of us which we used to store my water bottle and snacks.

Advertisement

My favourite thing about the flight was the incredible views of Scotland below.

The plane's engine was rather loud, so my partner and I didn't talk much during the flight. But we didn't mind — the scenery from the window kept us entertained.

I loved watching the city fold into the countryside from above.

The scenery got better as the flight continued.

As we got closer to Barra, we passed a couple of popular landmarks, including Loch Lomond, as well as islands on the west coast.

Advertisement

I captured this photo of a rainbow from our window.

The weather in Glasgow had been gloomy before our departure, but when we arrived in Barra the sun was shining and the sky was mostly clear and bright. I saw a rainbow from the plane window for the first time ever, which was one of the highlights of the journey.

Advertisement

Just over an hour after departing, we landed on the beach.

The flight took one hour and 15 minutes, and it was undoubtedly the most incredible flying experience of my life. When we landed on the beach at Barra Airport, I could see everything clearly since the window of the cockpit was visible from where I sat on the plane.

We even heard the splash of the water against the wheels of the plane as we touched down on the runway.

Advertisement

The beautiful scenery made up for the lack of luxury on board.

Overall, the small and cramped space and lack of amenities made for an un-glamorous flight, but this didn't feel like a big deal seeing as the journey was so short.

Despite the lack of luxury, the scenery from the plane and the incredible beach landing made it the most incredible flight I've been on. It felt like a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and I'm so thankful that my travel plans changed last minute.
